flags.title: User-Contributed Project
flags.text: This project guide is not managed by MAKE staff.

guide.introduction: This data-logging shield for the Arduino makes saving data to files on any FAT16 or FAT32 formatted SD card really easy. The included Real-Time Clock timestamps all your data with the current time, so that you know precisely what happened and when!
guide.introduction_rendered:
This data-logging shield for the Arduino makes saving data to files on any FAT16 or FAT32 formatted SD card really easy. The included Real-Time Clock timestamps all your data with the current time, so that you know precisely what happened and when!

Relevant parts
  • Data Logging Shield for Arduino
  • 3.3V Regulator
  • Real Time Clock IC
  • Level Shifter IC for SD Card
  • Watch Crystal
  • SD Card Holder
  • 3mm Red LED
  • 3mm Green LED
  • 10K Resistor
  • 1.0K Resistor
  • 2.2K Resistor
  • 0.1uF ceramic capacitor
  • 100uF/6.3V capacitor
  • Tactile switch
  • 36-Pin Male Header
  • 12mm 3V Coin Cell
  • 12mm Coin Cell Holder
  • PCB

parts.text: Level Shifter IC for SD Card

lines.text: Check to make sure you have all of the necessary components to build the data logging kit.
lines.text_raw: Check to make sure you have all of the necessary components to build the data logging kit.

lines.text: Insert the resistor with color bands Brown-Black-Orange into the location marked R5.
lines.text_raw: Insert the resistor with color bands Brown-Black-Orange into the location marked '''R5'''.

lines.text: Resistors are not polarized, so it does not matter which direction you insert them in.
lines.text_raw: Resistors are not polarized, so it does not matter which direction you insert them in.

lines.text: Turn the board over, and then solder the leads.
lines.text_raw: Turn the board over, and then solder the leads.

lines.text: Make your soldering life easier by trimming the leads of the components after you solder them in.
lines.text_raw: Make your soldering life easier by trimming the leads of the components after you solder them in.

lines.text: In locations R3 and R4, insert the two resistors with the color bands Brown-Black-Red.
lines.text_raw: In locations '''R3''' and '''R4''', insert the two resistors with the color bands Brown-Black-Red.

lines.text: Turn the board over, and solder the resistors in.  Then clip the leads.
lines.text_raw: Turn the board over, and solder the resistors in.  Then clip the leads.

lines.text: The SD card holder has two humps that snap it into place on the circuit board.
lines.text_raw: The SD card holder has two humps that snap it into place on the circuit board.

lines.text: You should be able to feel it fit into two grooves and sit snugly on the surface.
lines.text_raw: You should be able to feel it fit into two grooves and sit snugly on the surface.

lines.text: On the sides are 4 tabs. Solder these tabs to the circuit board by first heating up the tabs, and then applying solder.  The holder shouldn't move once it's been soldered in.
lines.text_raw: On the sides are 4 tabs. Solder these tabs to the circuit board by first heating up the tabs, and then applying solder.  The holder shouldn't move once it's been soldered in.

lines.text: Now all you need to do is solder the leftmost 7 tabs to the circuit board.  It is unnecessary to solder the remaining three.
lines.text_raw: Now all you need to do is solder the leftmost 7 tabs to the circuit board.  It is unnecessary to solder the remaining three.

lines.text: In locations R1 and R2, insert the two resistors with the color code Red-Red-Red.
lines.text_raw: In locations '''R1''' and '''R2''', insert the two resistors with the color code Red-Red-Red.

lines.text: Solder these two resistors in, and then clip the leads.
lines.text_raw: Solder these two resistors in, and then clip the leads.

lines.text: The two small, yellow ceramic capacitors are not polarized, so it does not matter which direction you insert them.
lines.text_raw: The two small, yellow ceramic capacitors are not polarized, so it does not matter which direction you insert them.

lines.text: Insert them into locations C2 and C3.
lines.text_raw: Insert them into locations '''C2''' and '''C3'''.

lines.text: Solder them in, and then clip the leads.
lines.text_raw: Solder them in, and then clip the leads.

lines.text: Electrolytic capacitors are polarized, so it is important to insert them properly.
lines.text_raw: Electrolytic capacitors are polarized, so it is important to insert them properly.

lines.text: The longer lead is the "+" lead, so make sure you enter this lead into the hole marked with the "+.
lines.text_raw: The longer lead is the "+" lead, so make sure you enter this lead into the hole marked with the "+.

lines.text: Insert them into locations C1 and C4. Solder them in, and then clip the leads.
lines.text_raw: Insert them into locations '''C1''' and '''C4'''.  Solder them in, and then clip the leads.

lines.text: Insert the 3.3V Regulator.
lines.text_raw: Insert the 3.3V Regulator.

lines.text: In location IC1, insert the regulator with its flat end matched up with the flat side of the silk-screened image on the circuit board.
lines.text_raw: In location '''IC1''', insert the regulator with its flat end matched up with the flat side of the silk-screened image on the circuit board.

lines.text: Solder the leads in, and then clip them.
lines.text_raw: Solder the leads in, and then clip them.

lines.text: The socket has a notch on one end. This notch must match the one in the picture silk-screened onto the circuit board.
lines.text_raw: The socket has a notch on one end. This notch must match the one in the picture silk-screened onto the circuit board.

lines.text: Make sure the socket is flush with the circuit board when you turn it over to solder.
lines.text_raw: Make sure the socket is flush with the circuit board when you turn it over to solder.

lines.text: Once the socket is soldered in, you can insert the IC into the socket.
lines.text_raw: Once the socket is soldered in, you can insert the IC into the socket.

lines.text: The longer chip will be inserted into location IC3 without a socket. It is important to make sure that the end of the chip with the notch matches up with the the notch on the silk-screened image.
lines.text_raw: The longer chip will be inserted into location '''IC3''' without a socket. It is important to make sure that the end of the chip with the notch matches up with the the notch on the silk-screened image.

lines.text: Turn the board over and solder the chip into the circuit board.
lines.text_raw: Turn the board over and solder the chip into the circuit board.

lines.text: Deposit a bit of solder on the center tab of the location marked BAT.
lines.text_raw: Deposit a bit of solder on the center tab of the location marked '''BAT'''.

lines.text: Now you can insert the metal battery holder and solder it in.
lines.text_raw: Now you can insert the metal battery holder and solder it in.

lines.text: The reset button is inserted into the location marked RESET.
lines.text_raw: The reset button is inserted into the location marked '''RESET'''.

lines.text: Press the button all the way into the circuit board.  Turn the board over and solder it in.
lines.text_raw: Press the button all the way into the circuit board.  Turn the board over and solder it in.

lines.text: In location LED1, insert the green LED. The longer lead of the LED should be inserted into the hole marked "+" on the circuit board.
lines.text_raw: In location '''LED1''', insert the green LED.  The longer lead of the LED should be inserted into the hole marked "+" on the circuit board.

lines.text: In location LED2, insert the red LED. Just as with the green LED, insert the longer lead of the LED into the hole marked with the "+".
lines.text_raw: In location '''LED2''', insert the red LED.  Just as with the green LED, insert the longer lead of the LED into the hole marked with the "+".

lines.text: In location Q1, insert the small metal cylinder. The crystal is not polarized, so you can insert it in any direction.
lines.text_raw: In location '''Q1''', insert the small metal cylinder.  The crystal is not polarized, so you can insert it in any direction.

lines.text: Solder it in, and then clip the leads.
lines.text_raw: Solder it in, and then clip the leads.

lines.text: From the 36-pin header, clip two 8-pin and two 6-pin headers.
lines.text_raw: From the 36-pin header, clip two 8-pin and two 6-pin headers.

lines.text: Insert the longer end of the headers into the female headers on the Arduino.
lines.text_raw: Insert the longer end of the headers into the female headers on the Arduino.

lines.text: Place the shield on top of the the shorter leads of the headers.
lines.text_raw: Place the shield on top of the the shorter leads of the headers.

lines.text: Solder every pin of the male headers, and you will be finished.
lines.text_raw: Solder every pin of the male headers, and you will be finished.

lines.text: Insert the included coin-cell battery, and you are finished.
lines.text_raw: Insert the included coin-cell battery, and you are finished.

lines.text: You can remove the shield from the Arduino, or keep it attached to the Arduino.
lines.text_raw: You can remove the shield from the Arduino, or keep it attached to the Arduino.

guide.summary: It's easy to assemble the datalogger shield kit; this guide walks you through the process step-by-step.
guide.title: Arduino Data-Logging Shield Kit
